title: Johnson tells ministers ‘we’re not there yet’ on Brexit deal
text:
There are still "outstanding issues" in the way of achieving a Brexit deal, Boris Johnson told his Cabinet | Dan Kitwood/Getty Images Johnson tells ministers ‘we’re not there yet’ on Brexit deal British prime minister says ‘outstanding issues’ remain.

LONDON — There are still "outstanding issues" in the way of achieving a Brexit deal, Boris Johnson told his Cabinet Wednesday, as talks to reach an agreement before Thursday's European Council summit go down to the wire.

Speaking at a short Cabinet meeting in Downing Street on Wednesday afternoon, the British prime minister said there was "a chance of securing a good deal," his spokesperson said, adding, however, that "we are not there yet" and there are still "a number of outstanding issues" standing in the way.

Johnson spoke to Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar Wednesday morning and shortly after the Cabinet meeting updated Conservative MPs at a meeting of the parliamentary party's "1922" committee.

According to Steve Baker, leader of the Brexiteer European Research Group of Tory MPs, the prime minister told MPs "categorically" that the whole of the U.K., including Northern Ireland, would be leaving the EU's customs union and would be in its own single customs territory.

Baker said Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) still has red lines "that the whole U.K. needs to leave the customs union and be in its own single customs territory, [and] the prime minister has just told us that is what he's going to do."

He added: "The DUP's other important red line is consent in relation to regulatory alignment to the EU and I understand that that also will be carried through; the prime minister's made that clear."

Baker said Euroskeptics want to see a deal they could vote for, but added: "Let's not get ahead of ourselves. Until there's a legal text, we're not going to make a decision. We've come this far. Euroskeptics always pay attention to meticulous and detailed analysis of the legal texts and that's what we'll do this time as well."

Johnson told MPs at the meeting that a deal was close but Thursday's summit of EU leaders "was still shrouded in mist," Baker said. "He said we're on the Hillary Step on the way up to Everest."

On Wednesday afternoon, the government put forward a motion calling for a special Saturday sitting of parliament — an opportunity for MPs to vote in favor of a deal should one be secured. It remains unclear whether the sitting will go ahead if no deal is reached ahead of the summit. The government will decide whether to move the motion to a vote in the House of Commons on Thursday.

It is expected that the Saturday sitting will run from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. but ultimately the decision on timing will be for MPs, who must vote for the motion to guarantee the sitting takes place.
description: British prime minister says ‘outstanding issues’ remain.
